Unlike the other omakase places that I had been, they usually came with just a piece each.Our order started with:- Seaweed with Radish foamy soup that almost didn't taste like seaweed at all, it's refreshing, it's like jelly dessert, a bit too sweet, but I liked it. (just found the name: Muzuku with Nagaimo)- Toro: this is where I said, "if we started with this, all these fishes coming up next, better be as good", because you can't go wrong with Toro unless it's not fresh. Theirs was pretty big portion and yet it still melted in your mouth, so delicious.- Yellowtail Belly: this fish was sliced thinly and still delicious, but couldn't beat Toro for sure.- Ama Ebi: this was alright, I'm not a fond of ama ebi and just like Shauna, when they offered to fry the heads, it actually tasted better than the sushi itself. - Albacore: this was pretty good too, I liked this a lot, the sauce was very different here. - Baby squid: to be honest, this was the dish that made me watched our sushi chef making it as it was so different, I've never seen it before. The sauce was a bit sour and it actually blend pretty well with the squid and sprinkled with a little sesame. They tasted pretty good. - Spanish Mackerel: this was Shauna's favorite, I liked the slices that they did to the fish, made it less oily and it's really fresh. - Giant clam: a bit chewy, yet I still liked it, different texture than the rest of the sushi we had eaten so far.- Unagi: I'm not usually a big fan of eel, but this unagi was delicious, the sauce wasn't as sweet as any other places, so I actually dig this sushi here.- Oyster: the only non-sushi or handroll that we got. Not really a big fan of it since the portion ws so small, I liked the oyster at Sasabune better.- Toro handroll: still good, but not as perfect as the Toro sushi we got on the first round. This was a good thing to end too, I wish I ordered Toro sushi just like Shauna to end it, then it would be perfection. The service was great up till the 3rd or 4th sushi, because after that the plates didn't get picked up as often as before and sometimes my iced green tea didn't get filled up as fast either, not that the restaurant wasn't any crowded earlier. The fact that the waiter spilled some water behind our seats and didn't say sorry was a downgrade too, but obviously I couldn't go lower than 4 stars. Our sushi chef, Masa, was so nice to us as well and listened to our every order, eventho sometimes a bit confusing, he would repeat to us the order to make sure he got it right.It's hard to satisfy me, let alone knowing that at least I'd be spending $75, the food better be great and it really was and our bill came up to $110 (tips and tax included) and since it's their 30th anniversary, each group was given a special cup to bring home as a gift. Would I come back? I certainly would, but not anytime soon, cause spending over $50 for dinner usually was too steep for me and this time I spent twice, but somehow I felt fulfilled and satisfied, so I just have to earn the money and then I'll be BACK!

Reviews.Author: Kurt S.
Reviews.Content: Sushi Gen is kinda like the "office hottie" that everyone talks about:  You hear a lot of things around the watercooler & only half of them are actually true but most of it is urban legend rooted in something someone said long ago... and kept alive by the same people that forward "email petitions" & "medical warning emails" around the office.A DOWNTOWN BUSINESS LUNCH HOTSPOTSushi Gen, as it is today, is pretty good.  It's blown up ridiculously since its inception but it's still a good restaurant.  It has the added benefit of being easy to get to from downtown & having plentiful parking.  Sushi Gen got absurdly popular after being repeatedly listed in the LA Times & the LA Weekly as being one of Los Angeles top sushi restaurants.   It's also listed as one of SushiMasters "Top 10 Restaurants in California" so LA locals know about it & the rest of the America has seen it listed on Zagat LA & we all know that Zagat is where restaurants go to become generically mass market so that pretty much means that anyone passing through town that can flip through a 3 1/2x8" book trounces through Gen's doors.BEST FOR BUSINESS LUNCHES?To its credit, Sushi Gen operates somewhat like a Tokyo kitchen - very efficiently & quickly.  Some believe their sushi to be the "best in Los Angeles" based on discussions I've had with folks there.  I don't think it comes EVEN CLOSE to that but it's certainly better than joints like Beverly Hill's Nishimura or La Cienega's Koi at half the price.  Sure, it's in the upper third tier of sushi restaurants for certain;  & if you need a business meeting restaurant, this is probably a good choice being that:1) It's got reasonably good sushi & authentic Japanese dishes (i.e. no bulgogi or kimchee here)2) It's got a variety of dishes that'll please the Japanese foodie as well as the "I don't eat raw fish" types3) They "put the hold" on the sushi nazi routine for noobs making it friendly for high maintenance types that usually bitch about 'not enjoying the experience' or 'rude service'4) It's on the higher end of the price scale but you won't care since you'll be able to expense the meal as businessWHAT'S GOOD?For starters, the wasabi is real fresh grated wasabi root, and miraculously they serve high quality Maeda-En tea, instead of stock Yamamotoyama. The good news is that because they churn out so much fish across EIGHT sushi chefs, they generally always serve fresh fish.  In other words, there's very little chance of you being served something that's been in the refrigerator longer than a day or two.  And when you know that the fish is going to be fresh, it's best to side with the dishes that are hard to screw up when fresh.  For example, the Ikura/Salmon Roe is quite good.  Additionally, Yellowtail, Albacore, & Salmon are all generally always good, (since most of the crowd orders a ton of it) & again, consistent in bulk.  What is served on Monday will be the way it is Friday with completely new, fresh fish.  Ask for Toyo-san - the older chef in the middle.  WHAT'S BAD?Sushi Gen is akin to a conveyor belt production line which is good for speed of service but ultimately weak for quality.  Preparation is often sloppy:  The rice is occasionally dry, the fish cut is very consistently mediocre unless you sit at the bar, knife strokes sometimes seems to be almost with the grain, I've had fish w/ a small bone in it, etc.  All you really have to do is visit during lunch to discover how often the 'ball' gets dropped.Also - something to know is that while their fish may be very fresh, it's usually of arbitrary quality.  Generally the chefs themselves go to select the fish but I really have to wonder when it comes to Gen.  And this is a point that seems to be lost on a lot of reviewers - FRESH fish does not equate to GOOD fish.  I think they serve so much sushi that they virtually become indiscriminant about the fish they select to serve.  It's probably because of all the "business lunch" traffic they get, who they figure can't tell the difference anyway.  (Apparently very few Yelpers seem to be able to as well, judging by the reviews.  I would not '5-Star' this place.)For example, one of their 'specialties' is Otoro & Chutoro... & most of the time it's laden with tsuji.  (fibers)  I shouldn't need to chew my sushi to this degree.  I order this for customers I bring but it's always the weakest parts of any meal here.  Also Sushi Gen serves very poor Uni.  It's usually firm, bright, & well textured... but ultimately bitter/tasteless instead of being sweet.CONCLUSION:I'll have lunch here & I'll take my customers because it's convenient & they serve a broad range of dishes.  The sushi's not bad & the atmosphere is electric.  But when I'm on my own time or I'm aiming for quality, I go elsewhere.  For those looking for alternatives, Sushi Go 55 & Komasa downtown are more meticulous about what they serve.  Or Hiko on the Westside.3 1/2-stars. (Rounded up)

Reviews.Author: Rod U.
Reviews.Content: 1200+ yelp reviews and 4.5 star average = mandatory try.Some of the best sushi in LA.  It blows away the best of Hawaii.  Everything (simple ambiance, great sushi chefs, great food) comes together perfectly to make an incredible dining experience.Every seafood ingredient from the large selection is fresh.  I'm not going to comment about each individual item suffice it to say, if you want to try the freshest example of something, just order it.  Portions are generous.The rice is very good.  No broken grains.  Perfect seasoning.  Perfect amount of moisture that allows it to lightly hold togetherOmakase is exceptional.  As with most top sushi bars, the chefs present each nigiri sushi with the appropriate relish or sauce.  Sometimes overly creative making the sushi difficult to eat without loosing the garnish but always accentuating the flavor of the seafood and never overpowering it.  (Eat your sushi with your fingers not your chopsticks and you won't have any problems).The chefs behind the bar do an excellent job engaging you in conversation and keeping you entertained.Prices are very good.  Expect to pay $50 per person.Note:  If you are looking for creative, inside out rolls with 15 kinds of fish deep fried with 10 different sauces, go elsewhere.  This is sushi for the purist.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Author: Malena D.
Reviews.Content: I drove to little Tokyo on my day off for some ramen, but it was hot and sushi sounded like a much better idea.  So, we wandered over to Sushi Gen and queued up.  We made the first seating!yay! and sat down at the counter and started ordering.  Our sushi chef (Masatsu?) was prompt, professional and informative.  I was dining with a friend who is new to sushi, so I wanted to be very sure of what I ordered.Everything was fresh and oishi, delicious!  I was especially happy with the yellowtail and the sea eel.  I haven't had sea eel since I was in Tsukiji, Tokyo!  I really enjoyed the sushi and hot, hot tea.  This place is my kind of place, straight up good fish.  Arigato Sushi Gen!  I'll be back.

Reviews.Author: Marina T.
Reviews.Content: I've been here once before for the lunch specials and I loved it! I finally got to come back last week but decided to sit at the sushi bar for a less wait time. No lunch specials at the sushi bar and a minimum of 4 orders per person. We ate salmon, yellowtail, tamago, albacore which just melted in your mouth, yellowtail belly, kanpachi, and uni with quail egg sushi. Everything was amazing, fresh, quick. The sushi chef refilled us on our ginger frequently. We expected our bill to be much higher than what it was for the amount of sushi as well as the quality. I can't wait to come back again!! Only downfall is the wait time.

Reviews.Author: Bard X.
Reviews.Content: 400 reviews--everything has been said.  Yeah, yeah, yeah.  The best sashimi for the price.......with the most unique SMOKED TUNA and SALTED SALMON put on the plate for you to drool over.I am lucky to have great food advisers.  Chuy (yelp.com/user_details?us…) and Alex T. are like Dirty Harry in that they are incapable of missing the target--so get a 44 Magnum in their hand and watch heads roll.  When they recommend ANYTHING--I shut my big mouth and listen like a little tyke.SASHIMI.  You will feel like a GREAT WHITE (even if you are brown, black, yellow, or red) who just crossed twelve oceans biting into the side of every perfect specimen you find on your journey.  I spent the rest of my afternoon wondering if my teeth were going to expand into multiple rows and I was also very scared to stop moving in fear that my gills were going to miss the airflow (if I stopped) and force me into a deep coma.  So I walked Little Tokyo to survive--all while thinking about the amazing fish I devoured with the greatest company on the planet.This place is so good that I can only suggest bribing me to get a seat with Chuy and Alex to enhance the experience.  Just make sure you are a Trojan and have nothing but praise for USC--or else Chuy will crush your skull like a peanut and throw it on the UCLA Campus where it belongs.......

Reviews.Author: Susan Y.
Reviews.Content: I grew up in LA and love pretty much everything about it.  My boyfriend, born and raised in NorCal, appreciates LA but still prefers his hometown. One day, we were arguing over where we will live and raise our kids if we get married.  To his credit, he made some good points.  Norcal offered more job opportunities, better schools and a less materialistic subculture.  So when it came my turn to speak, I knew I had to come up with something good.  So I pulled out my trump card.  I said - "If we live in Norcal, we would have to FLY down whenever we want Sushi Gen."He was silenced.And that, girls, is how it's done.MUST ORDER:Sashimi Dinner with Tempura- For $26.00, you get a HUGE plate of fresh, fat slices of fish + tempura + miso soup + pickled vegetable sides + a piping bowl of rice- Melt-in-your-mouth tuna & yellowtail... big, thick slices that are fresh + delicious- Great spicy tuna + spicy yellowtail as well- Generous portion of hot, fresh tempura- Best deal for really good sushi in all of LASashimi Deluxe- For $35, you get an even larger plate of sashimi.  All sorts.  Including Toro.  I've never seen so much sashimi on one plate.  And such fat, juicy cuts too!  Absolutely delicious.  You really have to see this plate to believe it.- I would recommend this only to extreme Sashimi lovers who are prepared to eat.- If you love sashimi, then this is a BARGAIN.- If you like sashimi (and don't necessarily LOVE it), I would stick with the Sashimi Dinner with Tempura.- If you have leftovers, you can always pack it.  I know leftover sashimi sounds gross, but trust me, Sushi Gen fish is so fresh, you'd be mad at yourself the next day for not packing more.Uni Dinner- For $38, you get TONS of fresh uni.  And I mean tons.- Again, only order this if you can tolerate extreme levels of uni & only uni. Great deal for uni lovers though.- TIP: I personally love the combination of uni with nori.  This uni dinner is just uni over rice, with a tiny bit of nori.  I would order an extra side of nori and make my own uni balls.Amaebi:- The sweetest, plumpest amaebi I've ever had.- TIP: Make sure to ask them to cook the head in a soup.  I've never had this before anywhere else (they usually just fry the heads), but the soup is absolutely delicious.  There's an incredibly rich flavor that is just to die for.  From what I can gather, it's part miso soup, part chicken broth and a lot of shrimp brain, all mixed together with some refreshing green onion.  And there are still the 2 heads in it for you to munch on.Squid:- If you're a squid-lover like me, you know how heinous squid can be (in taste & in texture) when it's not fresh.  Not a problem here.  Sushi Gen's squid is absolutely fresh & crunchy & sweet.  It is still squid though, so if you hate squid, don't expect to like it here.Tuna:- There's no where else that has regular tuna like this.- I love the yellowtail & toro (I know, technically tuna too, but I did say "regular tuna") & salmon & albacore here too, but those are naturally fattier fish, so they have a higher chance of tasting good anywhere else.  But tuna is so lean, it can be virtually tasteless if it's not fresh (*ahem* frozen tuna).  And after eating the tuna at Sushi Gen, I just can't taste the tuna anywhere else.WHAT NOT TO ORDER:(note: it's not bad, it's just that I've had better in other places, and if you're going to a place like Sushi Gen, you're better off ordering what they're really good at):- Sauteed Sole- Monkfish Liver- Fried Chicken- Sea Cucumber- Lunch specials with teriyaki... I mean, it's just teriyaki. Nothing special. You can get larger portions for a better price somewhere else.This is only the 2nd restaurant I've given a 5 star rating.  It pains me to give 5 star ratings, because to me, 5 stars mean perfection.  And perfect restaurants, like perfect places to start a family, are few and far in between.  But there's no debate about Sushi Gen.  It is absolutely and without a doubt, perfection.

Reviews.Author: Cynthia L.
Reviews.Content: Sushi-Gen served delicious, fresh sashimi. My friend and I shared the $35 Deluxe Combination, which included an assortment of chef choice sashimi. There was maguro, sake, tako, ebi, tamago, ika, and even, toro! Of course, my favorite fish was the toro. Everything was good, from the taste of the fish to the presentation thereof, and even the service. I always had a full cup of tea and water.Cheers to sashimi and sake! 5 stars it is.

Reviews.Author: Toshiro D.
Reviews.Content: Sushi Gen - The Review by Toshiro D.Well well well. You are reading this because you want to know the truth about this wonderful little spot called Sushi Gen.Let's review stage by stage to be fair to the whole establishment, so that certain aspects which are good don't suffer under those that are not so good.1. Food: Los Angelians are quite obviously starved for quality food in all sectors. Why is that? Hollywood and California by its very nature places form over function, exterior over interior, so things usually look pretty and once you've been married for two weeks, the truth emerges. Well, food, business partners, Hollywood agents, fancy used cars, all have this in common in La La Land.As Californians were some of the first risk takers to attempt to eat raw fish on rice, they also still believe that they can get decent sushi in their restaurants, or that they even know what decent sushi is. They can't. They don't. Sushi Gen is one of those few spots that pulls ever so slightly above the basic absolutely rubberific quality of most sushi joints, that everyone raves about it. They also rave because like that most disgusting hot dog joint pinks, lots of people like to line up for it. Call it the Studio 54 syndrome. Followers bring followers. And so lots of people run here. Moreover, as Korean culture has seemingly displaced Japanese in town, this place functions as an anomaly as many Koreans like to eat here and yet, there are a few Japanese chefs and servers around (probably because at one point this was a Japanese run restaurant). Also, the Chinese seem to like the place too. One thing I did notice and this is always a tell tale sign - there were no Japanese people around. Hmmmmm. Oh wait, sorry, there were some Japanese looking people. But they were clearly born here the way they garbled their "sumi-masen" in that showy "I speak Japanese- Valley girl" sort of way.Well, that said, the food is good. It is nice. It is better than ok. It is not worth though the likely 100 bucks it will cost per head to eat what would amount to a 17-25 dollar meal at the best sushi restaurant in Vancouver. Vancouver - where they catch the fish and walk it over to you, kill it and serve. Yes. Really. WTF??? Oh, but let's leave that to the price area. So bottom line, I like their food. But I don't love their food. The red snapper was tiny. The salmon was good and the uni (sea urchin) was the one thing that really stood out. But not for the price. Not at all. Verdict on food - if you have never had good raw fish on rice prepared by Japanese chefs, try this place after you have first tried Matsuhisa and in Little Tokyo, the more reasonably priced and better tasting Mako Sushi and Hama Sushi.2. Sushi Chefs - They are polite, attentive, friendly, engaging and yes, actually Japanese. They seem to know their stuff. I was impressed but clearly, they have been dulled down and let down by the environment that they are in. You can clearly see the frustration on their faces when they suggest something in answer to a customer query and the response is "um like, do you have spicy tuna rolls". Yes. No Japanese culinary education going on here and that obviously sours the mood. Go down the street to KokeKokko and ask that question. The answer may be Sepukku. Anyway, I give them 5 stars on their chefs.3. Servers - Rude, arrogant, obnoxious Yep. Several experiences. All the same. They are not Japanese. And the attitude reminds me of my experiences living in Hong Kong. When I asked about the cost of the bill which was incomprehensible, the waitress took so much glee in trying to humiliate me by loudly running through the price of each item while I, in a low voice, kept saying that it was fine, no prob, ok, stop, please, stop. Yah. What is this about? Well, it sort of works in a chinese or korean spot where you expect the abrupt, rude, funtime experience. But in a restaurant where you just spent 500 bucks for 2 people and want to kill yourself, no, not really acceptable at all.So, 0/5 for their staff. And this is based on multiple experiences. The hosts are better. But actually, if they don't watch and manage their staff, they suck too. And believe me California people, Asians know when they are being rude. It is not part of the culture. Especially not when you are paying. You get treated this way because you encourage it. It's the Rodeo Drive, spit on me, sort of mentality. The more spit, the better it is.Price - Hahahahahahahaha! Like lol times 1000. They have to be kidding. Honestly. Like 10-15 bucks for a piece of uni. Let's all go away, catch some sea urchin and choppy choppy. The prices are bloody insane and totally out of whack with reality. I like how no amounts are listed on the sushi menu. It's all a big "face" scam. Read Noble House and learn about "face" sometime. Ok, so that's the review. It's the truth. Go elsewhere. Go to Mako Sushi.

Reviews.Author: Lei B.
Reviews.Content: My most recent visit here was on a whim. Going here solo I requested sitting at the sushi bar, the hostess made note that I had to order a minimum of 4 items. I laughed in my head because that would be no problem for me. Right as a sat down Chef Masato greeted me with a warm welcome and got down to business. As I was thinking of what to order, unexpectedly I said the one word that shocked myself and Chef Masato....OMAKASE....I've been here a couple times before but it was my first time ordering omakase here and I was excited for what was in store.I told Chef Masato not to hold back on anything and here's what he dished out to me in order...- Toro Sushi- Sayori (Needle fish) Sushi with fresh grated ginger- Spanish Mackerel- Jack Mackerel- Red Snapper with yuzu- Giant Clam- Uni- Salmon Roe- Yellowtail Belly- KanpachiEverything was so fresh and delicious. My favorites were the toro, yellowtail, red snapper and kanpachi. So good in fact I ordered more of it in addition to sweet shrimp and a toro hand roll. Yup, that's the way I handle things at a sushi restaurant...I mean business! With the sweet shrimp I had the option of having the head fried or in a miso soup. Today I picked the soup and it was served piping hot.Overall experience was great, omakase was great but not the best I've had. The best by far for me has been Sushi Ota in San Diego and Sushi Sasabune next.  I still need to try Sushi Zo and in the faaaar future Urasawa!

Reviews.Author: Mandy F.
Reviews.Content: Very fresh sushi except the long wait.... (1.5 hours+)

Reviews.Author: Max M.
Reviews.Content: Sushi Gen is probably the best sushi value-wise in all of LA. I used to buy seafood at International Marine which is where most sushi chefs buy their fish. So I know fresh sushi when I see and taste it.Sushi Gen may not have the highest quality raw fish, but the quality is consistently strong at the price point. The reason is that every Asian worker in the downtown area usually hits this place up once a week. Hence, the turnover is really high. Raw fish is expensive. Most sushi places cannot afford to stay in business if they threw away fish that didn't sell that day. This leads to a situation where most sushi restaurants serve you raw fish that is essentially a few days old. Yuck!If you know how to order, then you can easily eat well for $40 a person. I think the Tuna is always very fresh. Here is what I usually get:Tuna 2 pcsAlbacore 2 pcsHamachi (ask for the belly! It is the same price, but way better) 4 pcsAma Ebi 2 pcs Fluke fin 2 pcs. (ask for Yuzu Kosho or frsh lemon juice with salt)Salmon Belly 2 pcs.Spicy Tuna roll (they season with an unconventional chili sauce. They don't drown their tartare with Mayo.)If you are still hungry after that, then you need to eat less! I always sit at the bar because you can build a rapport with the sushi chefs. If they like you, they will hook you up. There is always a line out the door so arrive early. Sushi Gen wins my award for Best Priced Sushi.

Reviews.Author: Edison T.
Reviews.Content: Came here with my friend Steve for the $15 sashimi lunch special. Good thing for me he arrived at 10:15 and was the 3rd person in line. When I arrived there at 10:45 the line was already about 30-40 ppl long. No wait, score!The lunch special included miso soup, a plate of tofu, veggies, bowl of rice, and a giant plate of sashimi (yellow tail, salmon, tuna, eel, spicy tuna, squid?). The quality of the sashimi is super fresh and they serve it to you pretty much right away since I'm sure they have a lot of these plates ready for the lunch rush. Possibly the best sashimi value you can get for $15 bucks. I'm probably not going to come here again though because I don't think I would want to line up for 30 minutes or longer for this special, as good as it is. But if you have a friend who would get in line for you, then by all means DO IT!

Reviews.Author: Carrie T.
Reviews.Content: Very good sushi! The price is okay, some things are expensive such as the uni and sweet shrimp, but great quality guaranteed!The wait is the only bad part, wait usually takes about 45 mins to 1 hr on a saturday night!Started out with Sea Urchin (Uni) sushi! Super Fresh and melts in you mouth creamy...highlight of the night. Their Sashimi deluxe combination is great! Fresh fish and good amount of food to share between 2 people. Their Sushi combination didn't look too bad either! Their chicken teriyaki dinner is one of the best I've had. The chicken was tender and NOT dry with some crisp to the skin. Salad was refreshing and the service wasn't too shabby considering they were all very busy. The chefs were backed up on their sashimi requests, so it did take awhile for it to come out, but that didn't bother me too much since we had some food to start with. If you scan around the restaurant as you walk in or out, every table orders the sashimi deluxe combination, it's the main attraction! Lunch time is a steal! you can get sashimi combo for $15.

Reviews.Author: Carina N.
Reviews.Content: There is almost no better place than Sushi Gen. Period. That was the only thing I had in mind when I was heading to LA.... Sushi Gen engraved in my mind like an obsession.  I NEED. I WANT. I DESIRE.We were in the sushi bar chatting with the friendly Japanese chef, who managed to impress us by saying simple greetings in French, German, and Mandarin.  Skip the menu, Omakase is the chef's choice, and you can't go wrong with it.  We were delighted by the super fresh hamachi belly, medium Toro, and other amazingly authentic sushi.  The green tea ice-cream wasn't great (taste artificial) but they gladly changed it with red bean ice-cream for us.  I then passed out with sushi joy and satisfaction.  Thank you Sushi Gen.

Reviews.Author: Dennis I.
Reviews.Content: Did you ever have a restaurant that you didn't want to share so it wouldn't become more popular so as you could still selfishly get in.  This is one of mine and it's rating of 5 out 5 is spot on for a sushi bar.  So enjoy my recommendation and don't bother going (just kidding).The bad thing about Sushi-Gen is that is so good that you won't appreciate other sushi bars.  As a matter of fact I stopped going to other places because other sushi just didn't taste good and it's a waste of sushi dollars.  You'll understand if you go to here a few times.I've eaten at Matsuhisa, Hama Sushi, Sushi Roku, Asakuma, R23, and all those little joints in Little Tokyo plus numerous others.  Sushi-Gen is still the real deal for me and anyone I've taken there.  The sushi will spoil you for good so be careful.I like to start off with Hamachi (Yellow Tail).  Thought I knew hamachi, but   their hamachi is like creamy yummy.  It's not only super fresh, but hand picked (they have a fish buyer in Japan).   Then I usually go for Tai (Japanese Snapper).  It's a very mild tender white fish that they top with some salt and maybe yuzu (citrus).  You don't dip this into soy sauce, just stick it in your mouth and you'll say 'ahhh... yum'.  Next, I go for Aji (Japanese fresh mackerel) which has a dollop of ginger, green onion, and ponzu sauce.  It's a little more strong in flavor but a lot less than you'd imagine (mackerel).  I don't ever order this anymore at other restaurants as it's too strong for me.  You should try it if you never had it.  After this I need to chill and maybe order a sushi scallop.  They shuck it to order and slice it real thing with tiny lemon wedges in between.  Usually they drop a little salt so you don't mess up the flavor with soy sauce.  Wow!  it's good.Go for the albacore as it's prepared similar to the Tai.  Time for some fresh water eel (unagi) as theirs is really good.  They must cook their own.  Now it's time to order new stuff like oysters, natto, etc. or re-order sushi items I want again.Don't bother with the meal deal if you really want to savior the quality sushi at Sushi Gen.  Sit at the bar as you'll get the best cuts (always do that).

Reviews.Author: Amber M.
Reviews.Content: I've been to Tokyo and this place is a very close second. All their sushi is pristine and cut perfectly.  The staff is all Japanese which always makes me feel like I'm in the right place sushi. Highly recommend if in the LA area as a must go to sushi spot!

Reviews.Author: Diana I.
Reviews.Content: I made it back here, this time for LUNCH because I was dying to try their $15 sashimi lunch combo which by the way is a STEAL! I came with 3 other friends. They ordered the chirashi bowl which is sashimi on top of rice in a bowl. It's pretty much what I got but mine had the sashimi on a separate plate, and mine came with more sashimi, and more rice, AND miso soup AND salad AND this mini tofu dish. This is what I mean by a steal! The $15 price is seriously too good to be true. And the sashimi quality is amazingggg! SOOOO FRESH!! I'm salivating right now thinking about it. I also ordered 1 albacore sushi separate because I love albacore and they seriously do it right here! Amazing!So if you want in on this, make sure you come at lunch for the $15 price and order the SASHIMI lunch combo (not the sushi combo).Service was also spectacular! Our waitress was super sweet and took good care of us. This is still, hands down my favorite sushi place EVER! Nothing else beats it! :)

Reviews.Author: Miguel R.
Reviews.Content: Melt in your mouth fish at a good price - no kidding!!!!Came here with the world famous Armanaco N. today. I knew this place had really good Yelp reviews and not only that but 1000+ reviews so we had pretty high expectations. We had to wait a bit to get seated but hey it was the peak of lunch time so that was to be expected. They told us it would be 30 minutes but we waited less than that!The place looks pretty old school/traditional. It looks cool. The tables are kind of old though. You can tell because the surface shows wear. The walls are decorated with cool art but it doesn't really blow your mind. In any case, there is great ambience if you like to see all kinds of people. It's a pretty nicely mixed crowd that you get here.The Naco and I ordered the same combo and some iced green tea. It came out to $25 each with a $10 tip. The combo we ordered includes 2 rolls with three pieces each and 9 pieces of sushi, a salad, and a "wet"salad composed of seaweed and some kind of Japanese yam - as well as a small bowl of miso soup! That's great value really. The chef chooses what you get in the combo which we thought was pretty cool. There are actually places where the chef not only chooses what you eat but also tells you how to eat it and it costs much, much more than you can imagine.The miso was pretty good. The "wet salad" was interesting - we had never had anything like it. It's very sour and is cold. It looks a bit exotic - it has dark green seaweed strands and a white substance on top which is the yam. You are supposed to mix it up and slurp it up!The iced green tea was very, very, really, really ridiculously good!Every piece of sushi was mouthwateringly fabulous!!!! I kid you not, the fish just melts in your mouth!!!! It has a soft fresh flavor to it as well. I have read reviews where people say their sushi does not taste "fishy" and I can honestly tell you I have never experienced anything that resembles that sensation until NOW!!!! I swear, that the Naco and I just stared at each other as we tried each delectable piece of sushi! We were dumbfounded and knew that we would never be able to try sushi anywhere else again and have this experience. It's kind of scary. Now we can truly say we are sushi snobs! Oh, and remember that this is not - I repeat not - terribly expensive sushi. WOW!!!!One very unique thing about this place is that the soy sauce is premixed with wasabi. It comes in a cute little ceramic soy sauce dispenser. The sushi itself already has just the right amount of wasabi on it.Parking is available as the place has a pretty big lot and it is validated but I read that the validation merely brings down the price. It is difficult to get free parking around here unless you are willing to walk more than a couple of blocks. In any case, I can assure you that things will never be the same for us in the world of sushi again - a really, really great price for top quality fish. So incredible it's surreal - somebody pinch me!!!!

Reviews.Author: Stephy S.
Reviews.Content: Finally tried this place after the hype machine kicked it into high gear and I gotta say: Not so much. Perhaps it is my self-proclaimed sushi snob status, but the 5 star reviews are a bit questionable. As Jenny pointed out in her review when we walked in it smelled quite fishy. Usually that is my cue to turn it around and bail, but seeing as how the reviews were so high, we thought we'd stay and try it.The red snapper was good, although it was served with the skin on, which  is never a fave of mine :(The halibut was goodThe yellowtail was very goodSpicy Tuna, I'm never really a fan of, but in spite of that, I thought it was okay. The ankimo was a true dissapointment. I order this everywhere I go as I feel it speaks volumes about the place, but this was nothing to write home about. Super fishy and bad texture. If you want THE best ankimo with the tastiest of ponzus, try Sushi Ike in Hollywood. They truly set the bar.The lighting in this place also took away from the ambience I felt. It felt like last call in a bar, too bright and not appetizing.The beer and sake, sure, hard to go wrong with this.Overall, I think it's more like a 3 and a half, but I'll be kind and rate 4. Not horrible, but nothing standout enough to crave.

Reviews.Author: Jenny O.
Reviews.Content: S uch good sushi.U rchin of the sea, yummy.S almon is my favorite.H ands down best sashimi around.I nstantly melts in your mouth.G enuine sushi chefs.E xcellent service.N ever disappoints.Thinking about how good Sushi Gen is gets me a little delirious, as you can see by my sad excuse for a poem above. But, really, it's legit. Love the atmosphere, the warmth and friendliness from the chefs -- and most of all, love their sushi. Now, I love how warm rice tastes with sushi (Sugarfish) but Sushi-Gen makes me feel at home. The cuts are phenomenal, the fish tastes fresh and almost melts in your mouth. Great fish:rice:wasabi ratio + great service. Easily a favorite spot.Worth the wait. GO. The end.

Reviews.Author: Minda w.
Reviews.Content: Sushi Deluxe -  another OMG momentSure, the wait is long but for the Sushi Deluxe I will wait for you. I haven't had a good all around sashimi plate in a very very long time. This satisfied me to a T. I tried stuff that I've never had before like red snapper and some kind of clam. I'm also not a big fan of yellowtail but this one was really good. It almost made me like it as much as salmon. Everything on the plate was very fresh and tasty. I can't wait to get more. Love this place!

Reviews.Author: Adrian R.
Reviews.Content: Manager Jason is ridiculous. He will charge you $1 for ginger if you sit at the restaurant.  If you sit at the bar, the ginger is free. I inquired, and he said it was "policy." Notwithstanding the fact that the bill was nearly $200 for 3 of us, he would not budge with the $1 ginger. Amazing assh*le he was!!!  Next thing you know, he will charge you for soy sauce, wasabi, and chopsticks. I've been a loyal patron at this place for several years, but they lost my business over $1 ginger!On to Sushi-Boy or San-Sai...at least they won't charge me for extra ginger.

Reviews.Author: Dee C.
Reviews.Content: When I lived up north, I was bitching constantly about the freshness of the fish.  Not as far north as Seattle (I would've rocked out here, this area is yummers for sushi lusters), but San Francisco/Bay Area north.  For some reason that never fails to perplex me, sushi in S.F., save the one and only Ino which my foodie friend whom I trust says is legit/pretty good, just does not measure up to New York, Los Angeles, and forget about being whispered in the same sentence as Vancouver and Japan.  Yes, I went to beloved Koo twice (meh) and Kiss Seafood (it's fine, but this place isn't a sushi bar).Now I am in L.A., land of fresh sashimi aplenty.  For as long as I can remember I have come to Sushi-Gen and I always leave content and full of the freshest cuts of toro, hamachi, and m i r u g a i.  At this point, the staff, including the all-important sushi chefs, know me as a regular.  The Friday before my S.F. trip a week ago, I came here and it was yet again a delight.  I got off work late and it was pouring rain.  For some curious reason, rain, instead of making me want traditional comfort foods (something spicy, something hearty), makes me covet fresh sushi.  Kind of counterintuitive, I know.  We sat at the bar, naturally, and Masa-san treated us to a wonderful (but quite, quite basic) omakase meal.My favorites this evening:Red Snapper - Lord, have mercy, this is fantastic.  I love.  It is white fish with a hint of translucence and it comes garnished with a little yuzu and sea salt.  You are instructed to not dip into soy sauce.  Just listen and insert into mouth.  If you're like me, you'll just smile like an idiot.  MORE.Mirugai - Anyone who knows me knows how much I love these suckers.  When Masa-san asked at the end if there was anything else we wanted, without hesitation, I peeped, "Mirugai?"  He picked out the best cuts and just spoiled me terrific.  Chewy with that wonderful clean-tasting finish I adore, the two pieces made me want to serenade "Hero."Toro - Perfect, melt-in-your-mouth disappearance.Hamachi - Sushi-Gen's yellowtail is always incredible.  It is just superbly smooth with this too tasty finish that just hints at creamy.Hirame - Beautifully done, this falls apart with the greatest ease in the mouth.  Lightness of fish with warmth from the seared edges and just a touch of yuzu and sea salt.Salmon - I am not even the biggest fan of sake nigiri, but Sushi-Gen's is this slippery baby that does not have that oily taste I shun.  It has a silky butteriness that isn't too rich.These are what I remember very well from that rainy Friday dinner.  So happy, I skipped into the night.  How I love how fresh-tasting, clean fish matches that nip of crisp, brisk, and clean after a day of showers.

Reviews.Author: Chau V.
Reviews.Content: I am not a fan of sushi and sashimi but I have to admit this place rocks.I often perfer rolls whenever I am eating out at J-restaurants with my friends. However, Sushi Gen does not have many roll options, so I was limited to a few choices. Well, I think it was destiny because in fact it gave me the chance to try out their delicious sashimi deluxe combination.Sushi Gen has an outstanding quality of sashimi. Very very fresh! Even though the food is quite expensive, I believe it is worthy with the quality. I will definitely come back.Parking is $3 with restaurant validation. However, if you are lucky, you can find a street parking.

Reviews.Author: Albert H.
Reviews.Content: I came here last thursday, because my (native Japanese) date said they had the most authentic sushi in Los Angeles, with ingredients shipped from Japan. Being ethnic-Chinese and American-born-and-raised, I can't really identify authentic Japanese.. But, I can tell if it's good quality sushi/sashimi. and WOW! sushi-gen was FANTASTIC!We sat at the bar and sampled our way through various fish. I had toro for the first time.. and whoa, melty butter goodness from fish! I totally loved every single thing we ordered, except for this weird flat fish my date wanted because it's very rare and expensive in japan (it was kind of sinewy? I didn't like the texture, but it tasted fine). The hamachi (one of my favorites) was guh. Too bad I didn't quite make it through every thing I wanted to try (monkfish liver, ono, ikura, giant clam, scallops), but there's always next time!The prices were great too, considering all the (usually expensive) high-quality fish we ordered. We came in a little under $100, and while not a steal, it's reasonable and definitely worth what we ate.We also didn't have to wait at all to be seated. There was space at the bar, the minute we walked in. The rest of the restaurant was filled and there were people waiting outside for tables.The best sushi I've had in LA. Maybe the best in my life.

Reviews.Author: Min T.
Reviews.Content: I joined Virginia D and Jenny B for omakase at Sushi-Gen last night. I've always wanted to check it out and I'm a fiend for sushi. From reviews I read, omakase seemed to be around $50-$60. I guess those people didn't eat as much as we did as we spent $110 each (this included tax and tip).Our sushi master, Masa, started us with a seaweed soup. Or maybe it was a salad. I first started eating it with chopsticks but it was slippery we had to slurp it to finish it. It was light and slightly tart with a pretty white foam on top. Our first fish was toro. Now, when you start with toro, can it get any better than this? No, which is why I asked for more toro as my final pieces. We also had:yellowtail belly- great, not as deliciously fatty as toroamaebi- the sweet shrimp were great and we had the heads fried. I actually almost liked the heads better.albacore- I've never been a huge fan of albacore but Sushi-Gen's changed my mind. It just melted. baby squid- I think all of us squealed and went on and on about how pretty they were. I hadn't had it as sushi before and I loved this.Spanish mackerel- This is my favorite of the mackerel family and this fish was so fresh and though "oily" like a good mackerel is, wasn't "old-tasting" like some places serve it.Giant clam- Masa said it was giant clam (mirugai) which I asked was the same as geoduck. Of course it was. I actually liked it better at Sushi-Gen than when I had it in Seattle and geoduck is from the Pacific Northwest!Unagi- Not over-broiled and sauce wasn't too sweet. I wonder if they made their own eel sauce?At this point, we were slowing down. I went for a full order of kampachi (amberjack) while Virginia and I split salmon. Both were good. We also got oysters, one each. For this, I've had better oysters. Or rather, how it was topped. I didn't even try it with the provided sauce. although not the best oyster, I didn't mind having it.Virginia wanted a crab handroll which I also split with her. I thought it was okay. I rather have more sushi.Jenny and Virginia split a toro handroll which looked amazing but I just wanted more toro!The only reason why I didn't give them 5 stars is the service wasn't great. Our waitress actually spilled iced green tea behind me and splashed my ankles. She looked at me but didn't apologize. Then it took them a long time to even give us little plates. I was bringing down the plate where Masa was putting the nigiri until the little plates were brought out, about 3 things in. Eventually we were given sushi with its own special sauces on separate plates. These plates weren't cleared immediately either and they started piling up. My OCD was suffering. The busser was better than our waitress though. The kitchen took a while to get us our fried shrimp heads out. And for all the money we spent, I was surprised we weren't offered at least miso soup or a dessert on the house. This is a litany of complaints which seems a bit petty but the reality was, I had a really good time with the fish. The little things wouldn't have bothered me as much if it didn't keep happening. I would definitely come back again though! I'm still dreaming of that toro!

Reviews.Author: Ellen C.
Reviews.Content: THIS IS MY FAVORITE SUSHI RESTAURANT! (Better than Sushi Go 55, Sushi Zo, Sushi Sasabune (in which Sasabune shouldn't even be included on my favorite sushi list.)I came here when I was an intern in college and had NO idea what to order and was embarrassed to order too much food or too expensive fish in front of my mentor. My friend then took me again for a birthday dinner and there was no way I was going to limit myself.A few tips:1. Get there at 5pm so you don't have to wait in line. About 20 minutes in, there were people waiting outside the door.2. Request the omakase. The chef prepares whatever sushi he feels like and you can ask to split it between you and your party so you can try different types of sashimi.3. My favorite: EVERYTHING. I LOVED LOVED LOVED EVERYTHING. I hated all these other sashimi at other restaurants but I loved each one! My favorites were the ones where you didn't need to use soysauce at all!I ate about 8 courses = 16 pieces of fish that day. AGH. SO GOOD. I'm definitely going to try to be a regular here.We also got a free tea cup because they're celebrating their 30th anniversary. Or 50th? Don't remember...

Reviews.Author: Rich G.
Reviews.Content: Wow a 20 minute wait at lunch time. Came in for the lunch specials, mixed sashimi with Miso soup and a cup of rice. Yellowtail, Blue Fin, tuna poke, spicy tuna, imitation crab, cuttle fish, halibut and marinate tuna all for 14 bucks! nice.pic here tinyurl.com/4twndpeMy lunch partner for the day had the The chicken teriyaki bento box with sashimi( much smaller portion) but still a deal. She liked the chicken but I ended up with the tuna sashimi  :)

Reviews.Author: Gina C.
Reviews.Content: How is this rated higher than K-Zo? Sorry, but 2.5 stars.After hearing so many people rave about Sushi Gen, I came in and sat at the bar (default for me!). It was nice seeing that most of the chefs and clientele are japanese and very friendly.My date and I ordered a-la-carte. For about 16 nigiri orders, our bill came out to about $180 w/ one tiny cold sake, which I thought was pretty steep!! I still feel that Hide is a much better price for fresher and bigger fish.  **hokkaido: our favorite. topped w/ sea salt. we got 2 orders  **aji: very disappointing. it was very stringy/chewy  **uni: decent, but not the freshest. and a little lukewarm for my taste  **ikura: i always eat ikura with uni. this was good and fresh  **saba: good, but i've had lots better  **mirugai: a little soft. i usually like my mirugai crisp  **albacore: very soft/mushy  **hamachi: also very soft/mushi  **toro: meh. it didn't have the marbled texture it usually does. it definitely melted in your mouth, but not in the succulent way  **kanpachi: very good! chef recommended  **tai: not so memorable  **amaebi: decent. came with fried shrimp heads  **salmon: bleh  **anago: i thought this would be raw, but it was seared. pretty tasty  **kani handroll: they didn't have blue crab, so we ordered kani. it was pretty bland.I was really full after this meal, but not in that super-excited, super-satisfied way that I feel after a meal at Echigo, Hide, Sushi Zo, or Mori. And I felt the prices were steep for what we got. Also, the rice was inconsistent! One piece would be tokyo-style (warm) and the other pieces cold. So strange! I probably won't be back.

Reviews.Author: Alex H.
Reviews.Content: Although I didn't want to revisit this place after my last review, my GF was in her "sushi" mood and since traffic to the westside looked horrible, I decided to give this place a go.Instead of trying omakase again, we decided to order every single nigiri item on the menu and a side of Ika/Natto.Although they were busy, the sushi came out promptly.  Most of the items tasted fresh, the presentation and creativity pales in comparison to Sasabune, Sushi Masu or K-Zo.  BUT our entire meal for two not including the alcohol came out to $130 so in that aspect, they get an extra starOn a side note, their natto is bland, fried chicken is good and they serve a mean yellowtail collar.

Reviews.Author: Catherine C.
Reviews.Content: Delicious sushi joint in Little Tokyo!I used to come here with my dad and line up by the door at 11 so that when they opened at 11:15, we'd have a seat and wouldn't have to wait in the long line that followed.I think the lines aren't AS crazy as before because of the recession, because the last time I came, there were a few empty tables when the doors opened, and that used to be unheard of! People had to share tables before. But that was a few months ago, so maybe it's back to what it was.Anyway, the fish here is super fresh and delicious. And they have a sashimi lunch combo for $15, which is totally a snag! And it's more than enough to fill you. Parking is $1.50, I think. Try it! :) Oh and afterwards, walk across the street and get mochi for dessert!

Reviews.Author: Anh L.
Reviews.Content: This place deserves every star.There is no lunch special, I'm reading all these reviews and I'm like at the restaurant, where is this special? excuse my fob English So I came here at 11:05 with mi hermana and there's already a line, the restaurant store says opens at 11am but they start letting people in at 11:15We waited for a while and we sat down at 11:50 anyway the prices15 for the sashimi combothat is the lunch price, the dinner price is 27i don't know if i would pay 27, but for 15, that is a lot of food.Comes with rice and miso soup! although I think you just drink the miso soup as there were no spoons!I believe you can make reservations!The sashimi tastes great! FRESH, although there wasnt raw salmon, there were two pieces of cooked salmon!While you wait go get the macarons from the bakery 6 businesses down!!!!!Parking sucks, good luck =] its down town la.When you're done go SHOP! walk up to the fashion district get some cheap ass cologne!!

Reviews.Author: claudia g.
Reviews.Content: still:FRESHTASTYAUTHENTICNOT super generous CUTS but just rightRICE (just the perfect amount of Vinegar and seaweed topping the best)MISO W-CLAMS ($2 bucks more than Komase and not any better) SUPER TASTYIf you like GREEN TEA ice cream- it's the best i've ever had...ECHIGO (delicious craft beer)!!!!parking is $2.50 with validation and I think they are now taking reservations.C- BAR (is right next door) and FAR BAR is just down the street.

Reviews.Author: Bugs B.
Reviews.Content: Rating: 3.5 If you're starving and can't wait, go by yourself, will be seated immediately, and boy was I hungry.... Tuna sushi - not bad, was expecting more, still dreaming about Asanebo's tuna sushiAlbacore sushi - the winner, melts in your mouth, will come back for it Hamachi ( the belly) sushi - not bad, I starting to realize that I'm not a fan of Hamachi cuz it's just too bland for me. Red Snapper  (w/little yuzu and sea salt) sushi - Runner upMackerel sushi- too bland for me Fluke fin (w/ lemon juice with salt) --too bland and chewy for meEel Avocado cut roll - good Spicy Tuna hand roll - last time I'm ordering spicy tuna hand roll at Sushi Gen, am not a fan of their spicy sauce --too spicy for me.Damage? Around $50 not including tip. Good service.

Reviews.Author: Albert O.
Reviews.Content: When I see that a place has 4.5 stars after 548 reviews, I often ask myself, why bother writing a review? What can I say that hasn't already been said by one of the 548 other people, who almost universally love it? Literally, hundreds of people have commented on how fresh the fish is. Scores of people recommend omakase, dozens of people have already covered the "I'm not from LA but Sushi-Gen is always on my list of places to go" angle. I can't deal with trying to figure out a unique angle, so let me just say this: Sushi Gen fucking rules. There, nobody's said that yet.

Reviews.Author: Dave L.
Reviews.Content: The best sushi in LA!If you're all about Rainbow rolls and Philadelphia rolls, take that kid stuff somewhere else. These Japanese chefs will serve you some real sushi and sashimi. You know how sometimes fish is all stringy and chewy? Not here. Premium stuff baby. And because it's so fresh, it's a great place to try new things. Did I mention the portions are huge? When I come with my mom and sister, we have the chef cut the sushi in half for them. If you wanna go, give me call!Tips: Located in the Honda Plaza, across the Office Depot in J-Town. Private parking is $2.50 validated. Come early or be prepared to wait outside. Sushi bar is faster, but you pay a little extra for the service.

Reviews.Author: Suzy W.
Reviews.Content: Sushi Gen is my favorite sushi place hands down.  I just don't like the horribly long wait that you inevitably have to endure.  There is pretty much zero chance you would ever walk in and sit right down.  Even 5 minutes prior to closing there are usually still a couple of parties waiting to be seated.  I always get the Sashimi Deluxe (giant platter of assorted sashimi),  tuna cut rolls, albacore, scallops, yellowtail and plum cut roll.  Consistently fresh quality cuts of fish!!  yelp.com/biz_photos/YBmk… The MUST TRY item I would recommend is the Yellowtail & Scallion handroll or cut roll.  It's a roll of buttery goodness with perfect sushi rice and quality nori.  You'll be hooked once you try it.  =)  yelp.com/biz_photos/YBmk…They've also got pretty good salads like salmon skin, seafood, or crab.  If you're in the mood for a steaming bowl of rice in light broth, they offer 4 or 5 kinds of Ochazuke.  A complete dinner for 2 is usually around $130.  It's worth every penny because the fish and the rice is unmatched anywhere else.  Make sure your whole party is there - this is one of those places that won't seat you without everyone present.  Parking is $1.50 for lunch and $2.50 for dinner.

Reviews.Author: Winnie L.
Reviews.Content: came back again last night.  i didn't learn my lesson the first time:  Sashimi Dinner is too big for me to defeat.  I walked out holding my stomach and back like I was preggers.  Last night, i ordered the Sashimi Dinner again and afterwards, I wanted to give birth to the biggest turd-monster as soon as i got home.  Next time I'm gonna order the Sashimi (not Sashimi Dinner) at dinner time, and save the $5 for other delicacies instead of shoving the tempura + miso soup + sunomono + rice down my throat.   Bulimia is no good if i don't like to throw up.

Reviews.Author: Thia G.
Reviews.Content: I personally think this place is really great.  The sashimi here is pretty unbeatable in terms of freshness, taste, and quality.  They've gotten rather expensive (sad to say) but I still like to come here for really good sashimi.If you're looking for rolls, Sushi Gen isn't really the place to come for rolls packed with a billion things, i.e. Americanized.  It's all about pure, tasty sashimi with rice (i.e. chirashi deluxe, or sashimi deluxe, YUMMMY).My only complaint is the wait, but I suppose with any highly coveted restaurant in LA, the wait will always be impossibly long... If you make a reservation, do NOT be late, not even 5 minutes, otherwise you will be forced to wait with all the first-come first-served people.Also they have AWESOME green tea here :)

Reviews.Author: Mai L.
Reviews.Content: Sushi-Gen's fish factor is amazing.  I love their yellowtail and they do have extremely fresh fish however, something is missing. In all my visits I've always left feeling sort of empty.Anyone can do fresh fish - if you have the money and the knowledge or even the right sources.  But  where's the heart? The passion?Maybe it's the fact that there's always a line and the wait can be extremely painful.  Then once you're inside the noise level is pretty crazy and then the staff is rushing all over the floor.  If you're dining at the sushi bar you get minimal attention from the chef because he's frantically filling orders for the tables.  At some point you start to feel like its all mechanical and they're just hastening to get a product on the plates for the hungry mouths. Overall, the service is poor and rushed. I suppose I'm not used to that and I'm not willing to endure the lines or the crowds for that price not when there are so many others that do it right.

Reviews.Author: Fiona H.
Reviews.Content: After hearing how amazing this place is, I waited for a special occasion to come check out the place, since as good as the dishes sound, they are still rather pricey.  So, when my mom, also a sashimi lover, came to visit, I thought to myself 'hmm what's a better time than this to try out Sushi Gen?!!"  Yay :)Sashimigasm.  We ordered a combination sashimi platter, oh my goodness the entire thing was so dayaam delicious.  Every piece of sashimi that entered my mouth was fresh and juicy, even the tamago was better - thick with brown edges, oh cooked to perfection.  The service was just as great as the sashimi!I can't wait for the next special occasion to come here! :P

Reviews.Author: Lucia C.
Reviews.Content: This is the treasure-trove of sushi-goodness! One of my sushi-crazy friends brought me here at 10:30am on a Thursday for lunch- I thought he was crazy, when I found out the restaurant actually opens at 11 am! but we weren't even first in line... we were second, &by 11am, there were literally 40-50 people behind us.They also opened the doors at 11:10am. OH THE SUSPENSE. This took longer than waiting for a disneyland ride.The sashimi special was good. At $15, you get a great variety of fish! &it's all pretty fresh. they also give you 3-4 slices of each kind &I was really full by the end (I didn't even touch my rice!).I don't know why I would even consider another place for sashmi after this. *scratch that* I would only go to a different place if I can't wake up in time to get ahead of the line. In this case, the early bird gets the fish.

Reviews.Author: Jessica Y.
Reviews.Content: If you don't want to wait in line and enjoy marveling at the work of each sushi chef's knife, request to sit at the bar. Trust me, you'll love it here. The bf and I always sit at the bar so we were delighted when they seated us right away, given that the line was 10 names long. The minimum order is 4 per person which is great because I can definitely eat my fill of sushi. Long story short, the sushi here is orgasmically good. It literally melts in your mouth and you can definitely taste quality here. We ordered salmon, yellow tail, halibut (omg this is to die for), tomago (just a tad sweet for my taste), toro sashimi, tuna sashimi, octopus sashimi, squid sushi, miso soup, and a large sake. Everything was superb and I can't wait to get my sushi on again! Tip: Order the miso soup, it's only $1 which is a STEAL for miso soup in J-town.

Reviews.Author: Ari K.
Reviews.Content: WOW, this place speaks volumes to sushi culture in LA and the message is clear - NaNaNaNaNaNa, we're better than you are!That being said, I think I need to move downtown just to go eat here every day.  Expect to wait about 5-20 minutes when you come here.  This place is the best sushi place I have been to in a while, and its not that expensive (comparatively),The highlights (Don't skip a single one of these)- Spanish Mackerel Sushi (the best), Scallop Sushi (amazing pop), Yellowtail Sushi, Halibut Fin Sushi (so chewy, so good), Spicy Tuna with Uni hand-roll (they may not understand how to make this, show them the picture I put up), Toro sushi (buttery greatness)If you're still hungry- red snapper (a little bit of skin is left on), large scallop plate, octopus sashimi (april/may only), oyster sushi (you heard me right), salmon skin roll (you better love salmon skin to get this one), and much much moreI would expect to spend about $60 after tax and tip, worth every last penny.  Try and sit next to the owner on the end of the sushi bar for guidance of what to order, he loves to take sushi noobs under his wing.  Enjoy!

Reviews.Author: Ken C.
Reviews.Content: I can tell you that this is the freshest sushi and sashimi that I've ever had. What's even better is that the prices are reasonable.  I got a sushi platter with appetizer and salad for $26.  And I got a sashimi platter for $30.  It was an awesome meal.The wait is always bad...If you really want to be seated promptly, then I recommend going in as soon as they open up for lunch or dinner.  They will only seat you if your entire group is present.I can overanalyze the fish ad nauseum, but I'll keep the review short;  best sushi I've ever had.  It's so fresh and flavorful that I couldn't believe I was eating fish.  If you're looking for a place with great sashimi, check it out.

Reviews.Author: Tammy L.
Reviews.Content: Sushi Gen is one of the PREMIER sushi bars in the Los Angeles area. It has super fresh, super delicious sashimi and sushi on a regular basis. The fish here is so fresh, they actually keep them alive on life support and carve away at them for each order.  No...J/K.  But honestly, the fish does really look and taste that fresh.The quality of the fish combined with the just moderate price makes it #1 in my book. My boyfriend took me here for my birthday. We ordered the Uni Dinner with Tempura and the Sashimi Deluxe. For those on a budget date I suggest splitting the Sashimi Deluxe plate.  It is more than enough food to split between 2 people.  And if you aren't quite full, go home and get boba!+Sashimi deluxe ($35): this comes with a variety of sashimi and other side dishes: salmon, yellowtail, octopus, tuna, fatty tuna, shrimp, and then a spicy tuna, cooked salmon, crab meat, and seaweed. It is a lot of food and very filling! The salmon and yellowtail were my favorite. It is SO buttery and just melts in your mouth. Other items-- crab meat, spicy tuna, cooked salmon-- were just mediocre. It comes based on the Chef's choice.+Uni. boy oh boy. I didnt even want my boyfriend touching any of them. I wanted all for myself. It was deliciously slimy and fresh! It was sweet and the flavors were all there!The prices are bloody insane and totally out of whack with reality. I like how no amounts are listed on the sushi menu. It's all a big "face" scam.Note: don't come here expecting Rainbow rolls, Caterpillar Rolls and all that garbage (which isn't even sushi). As mentioned, the fish is the main attraction here, so sashimi and nigiri sushi are what attracts the real sushi customers and all the Asian customer base. Be prepared to wait, b/c there is always a line here; lunch or dinner, weekday or weekend.Parking can also be a pain. I suggest parking at the JVP parking structure across the street.Come early or make reservations, it gets crowded!!

Reviews.Author: Jenny H.
Reviews.Content: Going to Sushi Gen is like clubbing in Vegas for a group of dudes. You have to manage your time wisely, arrive well before the place opens, wait in line, and hope you'll beat the rush and get in. I finally found the time on a random weekday to come to Sushi Gen for the famous lunch special. The restaurant opens at 11:15 on the dot and I arrived around 10:40. I was surprised to already see a few people in line, and I quickly understood why. People seriously start lining up as early as an hour before the place opens so that they can secure a table in the first wave of customers. If you're not in, you'll most likely wait upwards of 30 minutes to an hour. Luckily for me, I got in with the first wave because I was an eager beaver and arrived early as suggested. The lunch special is honestly worth the trip! For only $15, you get various cuts of sashimi, a few sides, and a bowl of rice. The fish is extremely fresh and just melts in your mouth (other than the cooked salmon, which is weird and doesn't belong haha). Sushi Gen also has the best spicy tuna ever. Unlike every other place, they don't cut the tuna finely. They leave the tuna in big chunks and toss it with a delicious spicy sauce that's not super mayo-y. Just arrive early and you won't regret it!

Reviews.Author: Steve K.
Reviews.Content: One of the oldest and best traditional sushi place in S.CA. Hands down one of THE best.

Reviews.Author: Risa Y.
Reviews.Content: One thing that I didn't do, but I really should have done was to sit at the counter.  This place is known to have a very long wait, so when we saw that a table was available, our hungry stomach went right for it... later regretted, but was too late...When you go to a sushi restaurant and you expect good quality sushi.  Sit at the counter.  Trust me, it makes a huge difference when it comes to quality.Anyway, counter or no counter, this place could be a little overrated.  It's a little pricey for the quality.  The way they cut the fish, texture and temperature of the sushi rice and the amount of vinegar in the rice was just not up to par.  The fish quality however was not so bad.I ordered the sushi platter and the bf ordered the sashimi platter and for appetizer we ordered ankimo... I don't know what it is in English since im so FOB lol...but it was pretty good.Service was ok... once again, would've been better to sit at the counter.  Next time I come here, I will sit at the counter and write a review again!

Reviews.Author: Lloyd B.
Reviews.Content: If you don't mind the 20-40 minute wait, you're set for some of the best sushi in J-town. If you love sushi, this is your place. Don't expect any fancy rolls here either, just sushi.I ordered the Sashimi lunch special. It looked great and was super fresh.yelp.com/user_local_phot…The prices are reasonable and the portions are good. Service was speedy. You really can't go wrong here. Unfortunately, they don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait for a table. You can sit at the sushi bar, but you won't be allowed to order anything from the lunch menu.Good luck finding parking and again, be prepared to wait for a table.

Reviews.Author: Sika C.
Reviews.Content: 4 stars for quality of fish but shy of 5 due to such small portions.  Also sit at a table to be able to order combinations.  Me and a girlfriend sat at the bar and ordered off a sushi list with no prices and bill came out $191. Things I loved was kanpachi, toro, regular tuna, yellowtail belly. Don't get the monkfish liver it's much better and softer at Hama sushi down the road.

Reviews.Author: Clayton J.
Reviews.Content: The WINNER and undisputed Champion of the Sushi world in LA in "my price range or a little above it!"  I have heard rumors of another as good or better in the nether reaches of the bastion known as BH! ~~I visited here during my Interior Design class phase.  One of our Instructors - John F. took his students out once a quarter, on HIS treat!  He was a pretty cool guy, Japanese national and pretty progressive, He forced us to use his first name in class!  No Mr's, No Sirs, No F-san...  It was plain "John."  But, I digress...This was early in my sushi/sashimi gestation, so I can't really account for much since this was years ago, and it was the ONLY fat cat in town.  If you knew anyone that was a true Connoisseur of sushi/sashimi, they came here.  If they were in LA from Japan and wanted sushi, they came here or to one other place...It's been some time since then, I have not made the trek back, yet...I want to come here after, now eating and enjoying sushi/sashimi in Japan, China, and locally.  I want to "come home again."  I want to see how the world revolves...  Will I get "MY satisfaction?"Yes, the wait is "EPIC."  But, I believe that, that's part of mystique, the allure of the place!  The crowds that surround the entrance, the tiny parking lot...  It's ALL, a part of the greater whole!  That is, Sushi-Gen...The truth be told, I want this place to live up to it's name and time honored reputation... Time will tell...  I am coming soon!  Wait for me!Sushi-Gen!  I am coming home again!

Reviews.Author: Christina T.
Reviews.Content: I haven't found ANYWHERE that beats this lunch special.  There's not even one particular lunch special that's better, but there's a few that are just about $15 for a full stomach, a large variety, and sides!! The fish i FRESH FRESH FRESH and the cuts are good, presentation is great. 1) Sashimi special : comes with one plate of like 8 types of fish on it.  I definitely want this one when I come back.  It also comes with a bowl of regular rice, side of tofu (yum!), miso soup, and pickled veggies. Doesn't look like all that much when it comes out, but boy, everyone at the table was stuffed and we all got different things.  2) Tempura and Sashimi: I thought I'd get a great deal out of this because I wanted something fried with my fish, but it was more like fish with something fried.  There was a large plate of tempura and then 3 different types of sashimi (two piece each). Comes with the same sides/rice like the first. 3) Chirashi Bowl: This one looked pretty good also. This had an assortment of sashimi in a bowl of the sweeter sushi rice, egg, and eel.  I would want to try this one also after the Sashimi! mmmmhmm. This one doesn't come with all the sides and miso soup, so expect to be sad when all your friends get soup and tofu but you don't. :( Everyone was satisfied with what they ordered, I cannot wait to come back!! Lastly, service was great, the host was friendly, the servers were very good with water, and the ladies apopolgized profusely for bringing one dish later than the rest. But no need, we were still happy :)***We arrived at 11AM -- exactly when they're supposed to open. There was a line going across a few of the neighboring stores/restaurants! COME EARLY! When we got in line at 11, and the place opened at 11:15, we STILL had to go on the wait list, wait for the first people to finish their meals, then wait til it got to us...at the bottom of the waitlist... CRAZY. That tells you something about what kind of food you get here! Ahhh this review made me crave it all over again.  ITS WORTH THE WAIT!

Reviews.Author: Jeong P.
Reviews.Content: I hate waiting. But if you want some of the freshest sashimi you can get, it's worth it. The deluxe sashimi platter is a great value and comes with a good assortment of fish, including toro. Everything here is excellent, including the uni and monkfish liver. The clam miso soup is tasty and refreshing. The service is hit or miss, but it's understandable since the place is always packed. The sashimi is so good that it doesn't even matter. By far my favorite sushi joint. Do yourself a favor and make a reservation.

Reviews.Author: EJ C.
Reviews.Content: I just ventured to this little haven a few days ago on a friday night with some friends.  Although we were uber hungry, we didn't mind the wait because it was well worth it. We started off with the cold tofu which tasted like well, cold tofu. As an entree, I ordered the chicken teriyaki with sashimi (sashimi or tempura, I opted for the former for balance).  The chicken was absolutely delectable...or maybe I was just really hungry by then, either way it was fantastic. Nice and juicy on the inside with a hint of crispiness on the bottom, which I really enjoyed because it added more flavor on top of the teriyaki sauce. The dish also came with a side of salad and pureed mashed potatoes, which I enjoyed immensely as well. I left with a happily full stomach and quite sober....can't vouch for my other compadres though. ;)

Reviews.Author: Shauna B.
Reviews.Content: *F*I*V*E*  *S*T*A*R*S*All I have to say is: Sashimi Lunch Special!It includes miso soup, tiny cabbage salad, 3 chunks of silken(?) tofu, bowl of rice and a small platter is the most tastiest, melt in your mouth fish this side of Tokyo for $15.The host is unflappable. The waitstaff is quick and friendly. If you're in the mood for just fresh sashimi, get the sashimi platter. Just a platter of scrumptious fish. $30. But no rice, soup, salad. Just raw fish. I've been here twice and can't wait to go back. Oh! Get there at opening time - 11 a.m.  Because the wait line only gets longer as the afternoon progresses.

Reviews.Author: Phung D.
Reviews.Content: Wait: They open at 11AM but you want to be there by 10:45 the latest!!! Trust me, there will be a line waiting for you. We were seated fast after we got in which is nice. I think it's at least 30 minutes wait if you come after 11AM. Parking: Get it validate by the restaurant but you still have to pay $2 during lunch hrs, $3 for dinner.Service: Considering how busy they were, it was pretty good! Quick and attentive. I asked for spoons and they were fast. I thought the food would take forever since everyone came all at once, but nope! Looks like they got the lunch special all ready to bring out for everyone just like that.Food: The main thing on the list to get there for lunch time is their SASHIMI LUNCH SPECIAL. For the amount they give and quality of the fish they provide, it's definitely a special! Only $15!!! 1 piece of cooked salmon which I didn't touch since I don't like anything cooked! 3 pieces of tuna, 2 or 3 pieces of yellowtail I forgot, 3 pieces of squid, 3 pieces of something, a whole mix of something, chopped up crab, spicy tuna, and 2 more unknown that I don't remember! In conclusion, it's GOOD.My friend also ordered the teriyaki beef plate for $12. I thought that was okay since the beef didn't taste so much like teriyaki. It comes with soup and salads as well. Ginger costs $1 during the lunch special by the way.

Reviews.Author: Cynthia Y.
Reviews.Content: Hands down the BEST sushi I've ever had in my life.Boyfriend took me here for our anniversary dinner.We arrived right when they opened the door for dinner & there were lots of people.We ordered beer and plum wine for drinks =)Food: tempura, salmon sushi, albacore sushi ( i love albacore!!), and the famous sashimi deluxe.EVERYTHING was amazingly fresh melt in your mouth deliciousness. must try! Service was great, everyone was nice. Food was excellent. No complaints :)

Reviews.Author: Yi Z.
Reviews.Content: Everyone raves about the Sashimi Lunch and I have to agree that it's an incredible deal at $15.  I bet that if it was priced at $20, 50% of the customers would disappear and if they raise it to $25, 90% would be gone.  Gosh, how I wish they would increase the price because one hour of my life is worth more than a couple of bucks.  I literally waited for 60 minutes before we were seated and then we chowed down the meal in 30 minutes.  There's definitely something wrong with that equation.Anyway, the lunch special itself is worthy of more than 5 stars.  Everything tasted super fresh and the variety was awesome.  There was even a small piece of grilled salmon that was excellent as well.  I think you either need to arrive a few minutes before they open so you're in the first seating or be prepared to wait hours. I clearly don't have the time to make this a regular weekday fixture but it's fun once in a while.

Reviews.Author: Andrea P.
Reviews.Content: I am in LOVE with Sushi Gen. Every time I think about the $15 Sashimi lunch special, fireworks go off in my head and my face and eyes light up like a little girl on Christmas morning!!! They give you so many different types of sashimi and it's all super fresh and delicious. I also really enjoy the salmon collar - SO GOOD. Try it.I think their portions are just right. It's definitely more worth it to come for lunch because the dinner menu is almost essentially the same but the prices are higher for dinner. I came here for dinner once with my family and it got pretty $$$$ so if you can come for lunch - DO IT! I wish it wasn't so busy all the time because there seems to ALWAYS be a wait, but I guess that's a sign that it's worth it and truly yummy!I will always love Sushi Gen. The end.

Reviews.Author: Rita K.
Reviews.Content: I'm not a sushi fanatic like my bf and I rarely ever crave sushi, but my goodness, this place exceeded my expectations by a huge margin! My bf loves sushi and would rate this place 5 stars. Why? The fish is just fresh and absolutely amazing. A friendly couple next to us told us the chef of this restaurant gets dibs on the fishes, no wonder why the sashimi platter is what everybody orders! The service is great, the waitress we had was very friendly and attentive. Every time I turned around to look at her, she didn't ignore me like what other restaurants have their workers do, she actually asked me if I needed anything with a smile! Whaaat, every single time she never fails to please us. My bf had the sashimi meal and it came with tempura (big portions), pickled veggies, rice, and i forgot what else. I had the teriyaki chicken meal which wasn't as great as the fish; mediocre chicken with simple sauce. I would order the rolls/sushi/sashimi next time! Good thing my meal came with sashimi as an appetizer! After a long day of driving from the  bay we were glad to end our day with a nice dinner here. I made reservations at 5:30PM but due to a fire, we were 20 minutes late.  Luckily the restaurant wasn't full yet and the workers were friendly about it.

Reviews.Author: Angie K.
Reviews.Content: 1000+ reviews?I don't know if it's because I've tried much better sushi at Japan, Korea, and New York, but this place was okay. Great for the price, (other places ran $300 for a couple), but definitely not the best and the most fresh sushi I've had. I was a bit disappointed because I had expected something on a Sushi Yasuda and Sushi of Gari level in NY due to the amazing 4.5 reviews. But then again, major difference in price so it isn't fair to compare.Came here for lunch and waited an hour. It was longer than expected. Lunch Sushi Deluxe menu was only $15. So cheap! Would only come back if there is no wait.

Reviews.Author: Mylinh H.
Reviews.Content: Four stars for food.Two stars for the host.We came before opening hours to avoid the line. The host told us to stand outside the door and wait til they opened and didn't let us add our name to the list. Fair enough. I was standing at the entrance when he came out and said 'you're in the wrong place' he then points to the line forming and told me to stand there. Geee thanks. FOOD: Toro, yellowtail belly, and salmon sashimi are to die for. The Salmon collar is a lot better tasting than the yellowtail one. I don't recommend the desserts here.

Reviews.Author: Anton E.
Reviews.Content: Let the masses of yelp reviews speak: this place is awesome.  I usually frequent affordable sushi restaurants so it is an absolute pleasure to splurge (courtesy of my beloved) and eat sushi on the higher end. This is the sushi restaurant of my childhood memories: drunk and friendly sushi chefs, traditonal decor, and a lack of crazy fushion rolls.The fish here is buttery.  I had the scallop, fatty tuna, and yellowtail belly and the pieces were quite suculent.
